column4: what would happen if someone changes the sources.list to debian sources?  I'm pretty sure that would totally screw up the system, right?
what would happen if someone changes the sources.list to debian sources?  I'm pretty sure that would totally screw up the system, right?
you answered it yourself
just curious if it could somehow work - though I highly doubt it
it's just that I noticed that apt-spy is available in ununtu
yeah, they pull it all over :)
breezy & dapper were not even binary compatible, I'm not sure about etch and feisty.
yeah, I used it (uselessly) on my 3k dialup :)
with a debian system I imagine.  It really works great for debian
yes. it's offtopic, but I used unstable for several years before switching to warty.
cool.... another debian convert.  I just switched
I'm slowly warming up to ubuntu as a longtime debian user
It grows on you. For me, it was suddenly not having to integrate stuff, it's done for me. I switched to debian from redhat to get away from rpm hell, and from debian to ubuntu for configuration ease.
that's funny.. RH6.1 was the first distro I used for sustained period of time.. then I switched to potato.
dreamhost is a debian based one, pretty cheap
thanks
np.  thanks.. lookss like the post-up <command> might do it
you would create a stanza in /etc/network/interfaces to bring it up
there is already one that says auto wlan0.  how do I tell it essid and key and mode?
ah, now thats a different question :) I've never done it so, sadly, all I can do is point you at man interfaces .
I've only set up wired ethernet there. I didn't get wireless until recently and networkmanager has worked for me
